@reubsjw: So, a lot of people are giving some pretty uninformed takes about puberty blockers based on the pretty uninformed take about puberty blockers contained in the Cass Review interim report. As someone who stud...‚Ä¶

data.htmlText:
Thread Reader

Share this page!

Tweet Share Email

Reubs J Walsh (they/she) üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏èüü™‚¨úüü©

Follow @reubsjw
Aug 2 ‚Ä¢ 28 tweets ‚Ä¢ 6 min read
So, a lot of people are giving some pretty uninformed takes about puberty blockers based on the pretty uninformed take about puberty blockers contained in the Cass Review interim report. As someone who studies adolescent cognitive development for my PhD, I have some notes. 1/25üßµ
Here's a link to the interim report. cass.independent-review.uk/wp-content/upl‚Ä¶ 2/25
It says "adolescent sex hormone surges may trigger the opening of a critical period for experience-dependent rewiring of neural circuits underlying executive function [EF] (i.e. maturation of the part of the brain concerned with planning, decision making and judgement)... 3/25
"... If this is the case, brain maturation may be temporarily or permanently disrupted by puberty blockers, which could have significant impact on the ability to make complex risk-laden decisions, as well as possible longer-term neuropsychological consequences.
... 4/25
"To date, there has been very limited research on the short-, medium- or longer-term impact of puberty blockers on neurocognitive development." 5/25
So, taking the first statement (in 3/), there's a couple pieces to pick up on. First, that the triggering of a critical period has necessarily occured before PBs are prescribed, both in cis kids with central precocious puberty (CPP), and especially in trans kids. 6/25
This is because CPP is usually not noticed until the first wave of changes produced by gonadarche have started to occur (and therefore that initial surge of hormones has already happened), and in trans kids, it's SoC to wait til the same stage, and in practice usually later. 7/25
Second, experience-dependent 'rewiring' (brains don't have wires, gang) is indeed really important, and we have oodles of evidence that social stress during adolescence produces glucocorticoid surges that cause lasting damage across multiple brain systems, including EF. 8/25
(e.g. sciencedirect.com/science/articl‚Ä¶; sciencedirect.com/science/articl‚Ä¶; sciencedirect.com/science/articl‚Ä¶)
9/25
So, experiences like precocious puberty, or even 'early normal' (less early than 8yoa) in which (age)identity-incongruent pubertal changes occur, are associated with these same worse outcomes *BECAUSE OF THE EXPERIENCES* (sciencedirect.com/science/articl‚Ä¶; sciencedirect.com/science/articl‚Ä¶)
10/25
Further, sex- and stress- related hormones/signalling axes interact enormously in this age-group, and the effect of stress on EF development is at least as great as any disruptions PBs could hypothetically cause (for which we still have NO EVIDENCE). nyaspubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.11‚Ä¶ 11/25
But late puberty? No big deal, and general clinical consensus that it's rarely a problem, though it can result from something usually seen as pathology (incl. e.g. hypogonadotropic hypoganidsm) in a minority of cases (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/P‚Ä¶) 12/25
So as we can see, if we now move onto the rest of the statement (in 4 & 5/), while these hypothetical concerns are indeed about things which COULD in principle occur, they haven't occured enough in the many decades of use of PBs in cis kids that anyone has noticed. 13/25
But here's what we DO know. Denying trans kids access to puberty blockers is associated with a 1.7‚Äì3.3 TIMES greater risk of suicidality, after controlling for, well, a lot of other possible factors (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/P‚Ä¶). Is this surprising? No. 14/25
Here's why this is no surprise. As I've explained, gender-congruent changes in the way your body is perceived occuring earlier than your peers is associated with psychosocial issues, resulting in(or from?) social stress. Same 'direction', but ahead of the curve... 15/25
Now, for trans kids denied PBs, it's gender-incongruent, and at the same time as peers. So now the choice is between *opposite 'directions'* while both you and your peers are moving fast (rather than peers being stationary) - or lagging behind. 16/25
Also, the damage stress does to EF development is particularly heightened by uncontrollable stressors (see 11), like an endogenous puberty that makes it harder to recognise yourself in the mirror and knowing there's a way to stop it and being refused access to that option! 17/25
Then of course there are a million issues like, does this imply people with conditions like ADHD, which affect EF, lack capacity to consent to medical treatment, or only *this* medical treatment. Hmm, wonder why this one's different.... 18/25
And of course the simple fact that if they'd listened to any of the many trans people with documented professional expertise on these topics ‚Äì expertise which, with the best will in the world, exceeds Cass' and her team's in many cases ‚Äì who reached out to offer support... 19/25
...,the problems with this would have been obvious, including the way that it would inevitably be taken out of context by anti-trans activists to claim they have proof there's really a problem, which, in their defence, Cass' team do NOT say, but still... 20/25
...,they chose to explain the hypothetical possibility without explaining the myriad reasons this possibility in no way undermines PBs being best practice, including the KNOWN benefits of PBs and the KNOWN harms of gender-incongruent, non-consensual puberty... 21/25
..., but also the oodles of evidence that (intrinsic) delayed puberty isn't a risk factor for EF dysfunction, and that PBs have been used in precocious puberty for decades with no evidence that exogenously suspending puberty in this way affects EF. 22/25
As always with these things, the equivalences with cis kids are ignored or misunderstood entirely by cis decision-makers, especially when they refuse to engage with trans expertise. 23/25
Refusing PBs to trans kids is a radical, evidence-contradicted medical intervention that has known harmful and irreversible effects. The notion that using medicolegal authority to withhold treatment doesn't count as an intervention needs to go away. 24/25
Providing PBs to trans kids is also an intervention, and one about which we need more evidence. But choosing between these interventions should not be biased by "I didn't touch them, so I did no harm". Medicolegal authority renders that attitude negligent imo. 25/25 END üßµ
@UnrollThread
(Small clarification. 'Times greater' is a bit misleading here. I should have said times as great. So, 170 to 330% of the risk of kids who do get access to PBs)
I've been informed this is the wrong link. Apologies, the interim report is here, but the issues remain the same. cass.independent-review.uk/wp-content/upl‚Ä¶

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

More from @reubsjw

Reubs J Walsh (they/she) üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏èüü™‚¨úüü©

@reubsjw
Aug 1
*deep breath* OK, look.
Is working for a defense contractor ethically justifiable? No.
What job under capitalism is?
We've all done unethical things to survive. The level of threat affects how far we're willing to go...
Short üßµ
https://twitter.com/transscribe/status/1554103509959823362
The tiny minority who genuinely wouldn't do the same thing in Ana's situation aren't the ones attacking him.

Most or all the people attacking him will likely never face a situation where their survival is at as much risk as Ana's, nor their choices as curtailed...
This isn't to say it's morally neutral. I hope I would make a different choice in the same boat, but I simply don't know. I'm trans and disabled but I've never been at risk of being unable to access even basic healthcare if I quit a job...
Read 6 tweets

readabilityObject.content:
So, a lot of people are giving some pretty uninformed takes about puberty blockers based on the pretty uninformed take about puberty blockers contained in the Cass Review interim report. As someone who studies adolescent cognitive development for my PhD, I have some notes. 1/25üßµ

Here's a link to the interim report. cass.independent-review.uk/wp-content/upl‚Ä¶ 2/25

It says "adolescent sex hormone surges may trigger the opening of a critical period for experience-dependent rewiring of neural circuits underlying executive function [EF] (i.e. maturation of the part of the brain concerned with planning, decision making and judgement)... 3/25

"... If this is the case, brain maturation may be temporarily or permanently disrupted by puberty blockers, which could have significant impact on the ability to make complex risk-laden decisions, as well as possible longer-term neuropsychological consequences.
... 4/25

"To date, there has been very limited research on the short-, medium- or longer-term impact of puberty blockers on neurocognitive development." 5/25

So, taking the first statement (in 3/), there's a couple pieces to pick up on. First, that the triggering of a critical period has necessarily occured before PBs are prescribed, both in cis kids with central precocious puberty (CPP), and especially in trans kids. 6/25

This is because CPP is usually not noticed until the first wave of changes produced by gonadarche have started to occur (and therefore that initial surge of hormones has already happened), and in trans kids, it's SoC to wait til the same stage, and in practice usually later. 7/25

Second, experience-dependent 'rewiring' (brains don't have wires, gang) is indeed really important, and we have oodles of evidence that social stress during adolescence produces glucocorticoid surges that cause lasting damage across multiple brain systems, including EF. 8/25

So, experiences like precocious puberty, or even 'early normal' (less early than 8yoa) in which (age)identity-incongruent pubertal changes occur, are associated with these same worse outcomes *BECAUSE OF THE EXPERIENCES* (sciencedirect.com/science/articl‚Ä¶; sciencedirect.com/science/articl‚Ä¶)
10/25

Further, sex- and stress- related hormones/signalling axes interact enormously in this age-group, and the effect of stress on EF development is at least as great as any disruptions PBs could hypothetically cause (for which we still have NO EVIDENCE). nyaspubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.11‚Ä¶ 11/25

But late puberty? No big deal, and general clinical consensus that it's rarely a problem, though it can result from something usually seen as pathology (incl. e.g. hypogonadotropic hypoganidsm) in a minority of cases (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/P‚Ä¶) 12/25

So as we can see, if we now move onto the rest of the statement (in 4 & 5/), while these hypothetical concerns are indeed about things which COULD in principle occur, they haven't occured enough in the many decades of use of PBs in cis kids that anyone has noticed. 13/25

But here's what we DO know. Denying trans kids access to puberty blockers is associated with a 1.7‚Äì3.3 TIMES greater risk of suicidality, after controlling for, well, a lot of other possible factors (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/P‚Ä¶). Is this surprising? No. 14/25

Here's why this is no surprise. As I've explained, gender-congruent changes in the way your body is perceived occuring earlier than your peers is associated with psychosocial issues, resulting in(or from?) social stress. Same 'direction', but ahead of the curve... 15/25

Now, for trans kids denied PBs, it's gender-incongruent, and at the same time as peers. So now the choice is between *opposite 'directions'* while both you and your peers are moving fast (rather than peers being stationary) - or lagging behind. 16/25

Also, the damage stress does to EF development is particularly heightened by uncontrollable stressors (see 11), like an endogenous puberty that makes it harder to recognise yourself in the mirror and knowing there's a way to stop it and being refused access to that option! 17/25

Then of course there are a million issues like, does this imply people with conditions like ADHD, which affect EF, lack capacity to consent to medical treatment, or only *this* medical treatment. Hmm, wonder why this one's different.... 18/25

And of course the simple fact that if they'd listened to any of the many trans people with documented professional expertise on these topics ‚Äì expertise which, with the best will in the world, exceeds Cass' and her team's in many cases ‚Äì who reached out to offer support... 19/25

...,the problems with this would have been obvious, including the way that it would inevitably be taken out of context by anti-trans activists to claim they have proof there's really a problem, which, in their defence, Cass' team do NOT say, but still... 20/25

...,they chose to explain the hypothetical possibility without explaining the myriad reasons this possibility in no way undermines PBs being best practice, including the KNOWN benefits of PBs and the KNOWN harms of gender-incongruent, non-consensual puberty... 21/25

..., but also the oodles of evidence that (intrinsic) delayed puberty isn't a risk factor for EF dysfunction, and that PBs have been used in precocious puberty for decades with no evidence that exogenously suspending puberty in this way affects EF. 22/25

As always with these things, the equivalences with cis kids are ignored or misunderstood entirely by cis decision-makers, especially when they refuse to engage with trans expertise. 23/25

Refusing PBs to trans kids is a radical, evidence-contradicted medical intervention that has known harmful and irreversible effects. The notion that using medicolegal authority to withhold treatment doesn't count as an intervention needs to go away. 24/25

Providing PBs to trans kids is also an intervention, and one about which we need more evidence. But choosing between these interventions should not be biased by "I didn't touch them, so I did no harm". Medicolegal authority renders that attitude negligent imo. 25/25 END üßµ

(Small clarification. 'Times greater' is a bit misleading here. I should have said times as great. So, 170 to 330% of the risk of kids who do get access to PBs)

I've been informed this is the wrong link. Apologies, the interim report is here, but the issues remain the same. cass.independent-review.uk/wp-content/upl‚Ä¶

‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢

So, a lot of people are giving some pretty uninformed takes about puberty blockers based on the pretty uninformed take about puberty blockers contained in the Cass Review interim report. As someone who studies adolescent cognitive development for my PhD, I have some notes. 1/25üßµ



Here's a link to the interim report. cass.independent-review.uk/wp-content/upl‚Ä¶ 2/25



It says "adolescent sex hormone surges may trigger the opening of a critical period for experience-dependent rewiring of neural circuits underlying executive function [EF] (i.e. maturation of the part of the brain concerned with planning, decision making and judgement)... 3/25



"... If this is the case, brain maturation may be temporarily or permanently disrupted by puberty blockers, which could have significant impact on the ability to make complex risk-laden decisions, as well as possible longer-term neuropsychological consequences.
... 4/25



"To date, there has been very limited research on the short-, medium- or longer-term impact of puberty blockers on neurocognitive development." 5/25



So, taking the first statement (in 3/), there's a couple pieces to pick up on. First, that the triggering of a critical period has necessarily occured before PBs are prescribed, both in cis kids with central precocious puberty (CPP), and especially in trans kids. 6/25



This is because CPP is usually not noticed until the first wave of changes produced by gonadarche have started to occur (and therefore that initial surge of hormones has already happened), and in trans kids, it's SoC to wait til the same stage, and in practice usually later. 7/25



Second, experience-dependent 'rewiring' (brains don't have wires, gang) is indeed really important, and we have oodles of evidence that social stress during adolescence produces glucocorticoid surges that cause lasting damage across multiple brain systems, including EF. 8/25

Here's why this is no surprise. As I've explained, gender-congruent changes in the way your body is perceived occuring earlier than your peers is associated with psychosocial issues, resulting in(or from?) social stress. Same 'direction', but ahead of the curve... 15/25



Now, for trans kids denied PBs, it's gender-incongruent, and at the same time as peers. So now the choice is between *opposite 'directions'* while both you and your peers are moving fast (rather than peers being stationary) - or lagging behind. 16/25



Also, the damage stress does to EF development is particularly heightened by uncontrollable stressors (see 11), like an endogenous puberty that makes it harder to recognise yourself in the mirror and knowing there's a way to stop it and being refused access to that option! 17/25



Then of course there are a million issues like, does this imply people with conditions like ADHD, which affect EF, lack capacity to consent to medical treatment, or only *this* medical treatment. Hmm, wonder why this one's different.... 18/25



And of course the simple fact that if they'd listened to any of the many trans people with documented professional expertise on these topics ‚Äì expertise which, with the best will in the world, exceeds Cass' and her team's in many cases ‚Äì who reached out to offer support... 19/25



...,the problems with this would have been obvious, including the way that it would inevitably be taken out of context by anti-trans activists to claim they have proof there's really a problem, which, in their defence, Cass' team do NOT say, but still... 20/25



...,they chose to explain the hypothetical possibility without explaining the myriad reasons this possibility in no way undermines PBs being best practice, including the KNOWN benefits of PBs and the KNOWN harms of gender-incongruent, non-consensual puberty... 21/25



..., but also the oodles of evidence that (intrinsic) delayed puberty isn't a risk factor for EF dysfunction, and that PBs have been used in precocious puberty for decades with no evidence that exogenously suspending puberty in this way affects EF. 22/25



As always with these things, the equivalences with cis kids are ignored or misunderstood entirely by cis decision-makers, especially when they refuse to engage with trans expertise. 23/25



Refusing PBs to trans kids is a radical, evidence-contradicted medical intervention that has known harmful and irreversible effects. The notion that using medicolegal authority to withhold treatment doesn't count as an intervention needs to go away. 24/25



Providing PBs to trans kids is also an intervention, and one about which we need more evidence. But choosing between these interventions should not be biased by "I didn't touch them, so I did no harm". Medicolegal authority renders that attitude negligent imo. 25/25 END üßµ




(Small clarification. 'Times greater' is a bit misleading here. I should have said times as great. So, 170 to 330% of the risk of kids who do get access to PBs)
